item.title: Explosion at upscale Havana hotel kills 8 people, injures dozens
item.description: 13 people were reported missing as rescue workers toiled inside the wreckage of the hotel.

item.title: European doctor sees "enormous" rise in U.S. women seeking abortion pills
item.description: "I think that's a really good response," Dr. Rebecca Gomperts told CBS News, urging American women to store the pills, "in case you need it."

item.title: Hillary Clinton says human trafficking is "sadly exploding in Ukraine"
item.description: The former secretary of state said women in Ukraine have "been the victims of not just murder and rape, but kidnapping."

item.title: Woman gets 6 years in prison after plane forced to land in Belarus
item.description: Sophia Sapega, a Russian citizen, said she would appeal to Russian President Vladimir Putin to intervene.

item.title: War in Ukraine, pandemic leads to higher cost of bread, baked goods
item.description: The war in Ukraine is having a direct impact on the cost of wheat around the world, which will ultimately affect grocery store prices. Industry leaders tell CBS News' Scott MacFarlane that consumers can expect a significant price hike in the cost of bread and baked goods this summer.

item.title: Siblings reunited after fleeing Ukraine fighting
item.description: Charlie D'Agata speaks with a brother and sister reunited after having been separated two and a half months ago in Bucha. This is a story repeated across Ukraine as families become separated fleeing the fighting from the many towns and villages taken by Russian forces.

item.title: Cops find half-ton of cocaine in Nespresso plant's coffee bean shipment
item.description: Workers at the plant in Switzerland alerted authorities after discovering a mysterious white powder in sacks of beans that arrived by rail.

item.title: Late dictator Ferdinand Marcos' son poised to win Philippines election
item.description: For decades Marcos' pillaging of the country's wealth was considered established fact. Some Filipinos expect his son to hand out gold bars if he's elected.

item.title: More evacuations underway as Ukrainians make a last stand in Mariupol
item.description: Russia is reportedly preparing to hold a "Victory Day" parade in the decimated port city where, despite relentless bombing, hundreds of civilians have made it out.

item.title: Intelligence provided by the U.S. helped Ukrainians sink Russian ship Moskva
item.description: Intelligence the U.S. provided showed the location of the Moskva, but the U.S. had no role in the decision to strike it.

item.title: Rescue operation underway in Mariupol as Russian forces enter steel plant
item.description: Ukraine's military says Russian troops are now inside the plant — the last stronghold of the city's defenders.

item.title: 3 killed in stabbing attack near Tel Aviv, medics say
item.description: Police said they suspect it was a militant attack and that the assailant fled in a vehicle.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine's "war of attrition" has begun, says European official
item.description: An official from a Western-allied country outlined a number of factors likely to play into how long the conflict will last.

item.title: Journalist found dead in Mexico, 9th killed so far this year
item.description: Mexico's state and federal government have been criticized for neither preventing the killings nor investigating them sufficiently.

item.title: American volunteers fighting alongside Ukraine defenders become casualties and heroes
item.description: "I'm young. I can take it," says U.S. volunteer who was blinded in battle. "It's the kids and old people who I really worry about."

item.title: Ukrainian soldier rescued by Americans
item.description: A Ukrainian soldier recounts how he was rescued by American volunteer fighters. Debora Patta has more.

item.title: Russian oligarch's $300 million mega-yacht seized in Fiji
item.description: U.S. authorities say the yacht is owned by sanctioned oligarch billionaire Suleiman Kerimov.

item.title: Police officer accused of raping 13-year-old gang-rape victim
item.description: The alleged incident is the latest to spotlight the high levels of sexual violence in India.

item.title: Inside a dystopian retirement village left by Russia's war of attrition
item.description: CBS News meets weary souls eking out an existence in a front-line Ukrainian town where Russia "can't do anything except bomb everything."

item.title: Survivor pulled from rubble almost 6 days after building collapse
item.description: Despite the glimmer of hope, there may be dozens of people still missing in the crushed rubble of the "self-built" building, and at least 5 have died.

item.title: American fighters seek to help civilians across Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian forces are being joined by Americans who want to help civilians affected by Russia's assault.

item.title: "Most dangerous drug trafficker in the world" extradited to U.S.
item.description: The U.S. had placed a $5 million bounty on his head and his legend as a bandit grew alongside the horror stories told by Colombian authorities.

item.title: U.N. condemns Haitian gangs recruiting kids as chaos claims more lives
item.description: The warning from the U.N. came after a video circulated on Haitian social media showing a masked pre-teen child wielding a high-caliber automatic weapon.

item.title: Contact lost with Ukrainian troops amid "heavy fighting" at steel plant
item.description: "There are local residents there, civilians, hundreds of them there. There are children waiting for rescue," the mayor of Mariupol said.

item.title: EU takes step toward Russian oil ban and new sanctions
item.description: If approved, the ban on oil imports would be the second package of EU sanctions targeting Russia's lucrative energy industry since the country invaded Ukraine.

item.title: 600 possibly killed in Mariupol theater airstrike, evidence shows
item.description: An Associated Press investigation has found evidence that the attack was in fact far deadlier than estimated.

item.title: Ukrainian children in U.S. custody find unlikely sponsors
item.description: The Department of Health and Human Services is currently housing 30 unaccompanied children from Ukraine in shelters across the country, a U.S. official tells CBS News.

item.title: Diego Maradona's "Hand of God" jersey sets auction record
item.description: Maradona said the controversial goal had been scored "a little with the head of Maradona, and a little with the hand of God."

item.title: Ukraine special forces show devastation after weeks of Russian shelling
item.description: As the siege of the steelmill in Mariupol continues, Charlie D'Agata is on the eastern front lines witnessing the destruction caused in the town of Lysychansk and speaking to residents who have withstood weeks of Russian aggression.

item.title: "The people of Rome are being held hostage by wild boar"
item.description: Wild hogs, which can grow to 220 pounds, have been a problem in the northern part of Italy's capital for years. One regional official says it's "now out of control."

item.title: Putin's campaign of terror leaves Ukrainians with "nowhere to go"
item.description: As lucky survivors recall hiding from airstrikes under a steel plant in Mariupol, residents of another front-line town share the horrors of life under Russia's relentless assault.

item.title: U.S. determines WNBA's Griner being wrongfully detained by Russia
item.description: Brittney Griner has been held in Russian custody since mid-February, when she was arrested at the airport.

item.title: North Korea tests suspected ballistic missile after Kim's nuclear threat
item.description: The launch came just days after Kim Jong Un vowed to bolster his nuclear arsenal "at the fastest possible pace," and threatened to use it​ against rivals.

item.title: "Death shadow" fossils of largest raptor dinosaur unearthed in Argentina
item.description: The 5-ton apex-predator measuring 3 stories from nose to tail was found eviscerated its prey with sharp, curved claws.

item.title: U.S. gets permission from Fiji to seize Russian-owned mega-yacht
item.description: American and Fijian officials claim the $325 million Amadea is owned by sanctioned billionaire Suleiman Kerimov.

item.title: Russia attacks Mariupol after promising safe passage
item.description: Russian forces launched a full-scale attack on a steel plant in Mariupol, blocking further evacuations of civilians. Charlie D'Agata reports.

item.title: Biden praises workers producing Javelins Ukraine is using
item.description: Biden's visit to Alabama showcased the "tank killers" Ukrainians are using effectively dame as the Pentagon discusses long-term production of key weapons.

item.title: Russia storms key steel plant in Mariupol as some evacuees reach safety
item.description: Russian troops also shelled a chemical plant in the eastern city of Avdiivka, killing at least 10 people, Donetsk regional governor Pavlo Kyrylenko said.

item.title: Civilians continue to leave Mariupol
item.description: Evacuations of Mariupol continue as hundreds of civilians remain trapped. Chris Livesay reports.

item.title: Mom saves children from close encounter with venomous snake
item.description: This Mother's Day, we're saluting all the supermoms around the world who do so much every day to protect their children — like this mom in Australia, who in 2020 sprung into action to save her two daughters from a venomous snake outside their home.

item.title: Russia accuses Israel of supporting "neo-Nazis" in Ukraine
item.description: Israel has voiced support for Ukraine after Russia launched its invasion, but has refrained from directly criticizing the Kremlin and joined the Western effort to sanction Russian oligarchs.

item.title: 100-year-old sets record for longest career at one company
item.description: Walter Orthmann's career started in 1938, when he was just 15 years old. He hasn't left the company since.

item.title: Video shows man taken to morgue in body bag — while still alive
item.description: A Shanghai district government said five officials have been punished and the license of a doctor revoked after the blunder.

item.title: How one Ukrainian town sacrificed itself to stop Russia's invaders
item.description: CBS News sees the remarkable tactics helping Ukraine's defenders, as dozens of civilians who escaped a battered steelworks head for safety, and more await rescue.

item.title: Mystery liver disease kills 3 more children after "significant increase" in cases
item.description: This severe strain of acute hepatitis has been identified in nearly 170 children across 11 countries in recent weeks.

item.title: Israel demands apology after Russian official says Hitler had Jewish roots
item.description: "This is an unforgivable and outrageous statement and a terrible historic mistake and we expect an apology," Israel's foreign minister said.

item.title: Parents of hostage Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria, meet with Biden
item.description: President Biden said at the White House Correspondents Dinner that he'd like to meet with them.

item.title: Australian jailed for 1988 cliff-top murder of gay American Scott Johnson
item.description: The U.S. mathematician's brother said the ruling brought "fairness," despite the judge deciding there was insufficient evidence to prove a hate crime.

item.title: Parents still seeking "truth" 15 years after Madeleine McCann vanished
item.description: But on this anniversary, for the first time since her disappearance in Portugal, the British toddler's family has reason to hope.

item.title: Fake priest talks his way onto U.K. Army barracks near Windsor Castle
item.description: British Army taking the "breach of security extremely seriously" after an impostor managed to eat and dine with troops, and even spend the night on the base.
